For the most part, enemies can fall into one of two or three groups. There is an enemy that made combat interesting on the first encounter, as it requires a specific way to damage it. Once you figure it out, though, they just become a nuisance. *Combat is pretty basic. aside from the two main types of weapons, you have bombs and tomahawks. I think I accidentally used either of the special items than I did on purpose.*The ending of the main story leaves a ton to be desired, honestly. The ending left me pretty confused. After watching other people play through the ending, I saw I'm not alone, and it's a case of too little information. This is a serious shame, as by this time I was really enjoying the story. I really wish we could get some sort of followup, because I REALLY want to know more.*Stuff just isn't explained. there's no lore behind any of the interesting bits. Like what is this dark world and why can I go into it? Why can I talk to ghosts? What are these ashen figures? What are these burning enemies? Why is there a bunch of conquistodors that appear to be possesed? what are these totems? What is this corruption stuff? What are these weird spidery things and spores? Who is the merchant guy and why have I never seen him? His letters talk to you the player, and suggest he stocks all the shops. Heck, What's the deal with the ending? So, looking at the list of pros and cons, there's obviously a ton more in the cons section. HOWEVER! This is not a bad game. I did really enjoy it. I even found the collectible hunting sort of fun. Do I recommend it? Sort of. I think it is a very interesting game, and it had a ton of potential, but the ending mixed with the lack of useful lore really held it back. Posted: July 10, 2014
												I've enjoyed Betrayer so far, having played quite a few hours to get a feel for the atmosphere, mechanics and enemies. I recommend it strongly if spotted on sale, and a warm recommendation at regular price especially if you are a cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like myself. The game isn't hard to figure out or learn to play, though the introduction scene is short and is not comprehensive. I would have liked to be able to practice more sneaking and using the bow before moving into the game world proper, as this is the majority of the gameplay. Betrayer relies on text in scraps of notes or with NPCs to transmit the details of the world. If reading a sentence of exposition or a super-short paragraph of dialogue isn't your thing, you've been warned. I appreciate being able to piece together ghost stories by finding clues with the 'listen' mechanic. Finding treasure chests and other goodies while stumbling through the wilderness adds to the experience.As I said, sneaking and stealth kills are the majority of the game. How stealthy you are to the enemy is not communicated to the player besides simple simple video game common sense. Crouching and walking are near silent, walking is loud, running is right out. Being in shadows seems to help tremendously, though if you are within line of sight of an enemy looking in your direction you are likely to be found out regardless. Detection distance is irregular. Sometimes I'll be spotted across a flat field with little ground cover, sometimes I can get away with it. This isn't terrible, but it forces the player to be cautious, especially since it is easy to be overwhelmed.All out combat isn't preferable because the player is fragile. A group of enemies is deadly, and it is best to pick them off with stealthy arrow kills. (You deal more damage when the enemy has not detected you yet according to the tutorial.) When hard combat becomes necessary, it is difficult enough to survive that you learn quickly not to charge into any group of foes.Progression is measured in areas you move into, as well as what items are available in the shop (which also become available as you move to new maps). The weapons handle distinctly and feel great. Charms add passive bonuses to actions (musket reload speed, run speed, stealth, etc) and most everything you need can be found or purchased. Broken or shoddy versions of weapons can be found on enemies and sold for currency right in the field from the inventory screen. Ammunition is picked up from enemies or purchased from the shop. The game also allows you to conservatively retrieve arrows and other thrown weapons' ammunition from dead enemies. If you miss, sometimes I've been lucky enough to find the arrow in a tree, bush, or in the ground far behind the intended target. Ammo bought at the shop is cheap, but money is better spent on fancier versions of weapons to start, and this encouraged me to pick shots carefully.The intial black and white visuals are what I heard and saw first about Betrayer. While it was a nice introduction to the game and set the tone appropriately, I eventually turned up the color to saturate the natural environment. This also grew tiresome because the bright red of clues and enemies was easily lost in the woody greens and fields. I opted for a medium saturation, and the game ends up looking washed out enough to know that there was color, but still allowing the red signals to catch the eye and keep the bleak, lonely feeling of the game world. This setting becomes moot in the shadow version of the world, where everything becomes black and white anyway, so I don't feel like it changes too much of the experience.Sound, particularly listening to the environment, is extremely important in Betrayer. The primary 'listening' mechanic allows you to locate plot clues in the area by briefly adding markers to your compass HUD. The marks change width and brightness when your heading to the item is true, then fade out until you 'listen' again. It's an old idea, but I like the system because it is not as precise as a simple waypoint on your map and allows accidental exploration. Simply listening to ambient noise is incredibly helpful because item caches and enemies will make sounds at a distance as well. This gives the player the opportunity to explore, avoid, or maneuver around these opportunities. I appreciate that different enemies will make different noises. For example, I did not figure out until the umpteenth ambush that Naturals have a birdcall idling sound; I previously thought it was an ambient bird sound from the forest. Again, this is an old idea, but it fits well with the gameplay and setting, and is executed very well.Mystery, suspense, horror, paranormal activity, and good old-fashioned, New World mysticism are all wrapped into one tight package. Hours of fun were had combing the woods, listening tensely, and hunting Spaniards. I'd give it a solid 9.2/10, an A-, a 4.7 out of 5. Play it, especially if it goes on sale again.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												If I had to describe this game in one word, I would say it was 'ambitious.' A black and white, open world, horror FPS set in the colonial era from a virgin studio? Most indies would rather churn out another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle/platformer. But does the execution live up to it's premise? Nope! Does it matter? Maybe.The stealth system is awful. Many of the later enemies have black and white color palettes, so you don't see them before they see you. Oh, and they can see you instantly from 50 yards away. There's a mechanic involving wind masking your sounds or something, but I never felt that it was worth the risk.And the game is plauged by a lack of variety. There are only five different weapon types, with varying qualities. There are only six or seven enemies. You can find equipment, but all it does is give you passive bonuses that are hardly even noticeable. Each zone in the game plays out the same way: find everything in the light world, find everything in the dark world, talk to ghosts and move on to the next zone. By the end of the game, you're sprinting from point A to point B just to finish the game. I haven't felt this kind of repetition since Assassin's Creed 1.Betrayer has a fairly solid engine. There's a myriad of graphics options and HUD options to choose from, which is always welcome from an indie dev. You can even skip the black and white aesthetic and play with color (recommended). That said, I did get stuck a couple times in the geometry, forcing me to kill my character and respawn.But if you can get past these shortcomings, the game is really interesting. The sound design is stellar. I can't think of any game that has such a robust audio department, much less one that is so integral to the mechanics of the game. When the story comes together it can be superb, but the story elements are all non-linear. Sometimes the story doesn't have the impact it should have because of this, even when dealing with incredibly grim topics like filicide.If you're a stickler for mechanics, I'd skip this title. 'Rough around the edges' doesn't even begin to describe my experience. However if you're more interested in atmosphere or story and you're not bothered by the broken stealth system, this game will entertain you for a few hours.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I thoroughly enjoyed this unusual game, despite a few flaws that became apparent along the way. I can't speak highly enough of the aesthetic - a black and white world peppered with red, incredible use of sound, and an atmosphere that gets creepier as the game and story progress. While some of the game mechanics do become repetitive, I found the story interesting enough to want to make it all the way to the end. The "otherworld" - an alternate version of the world filled with spirits and obscured by a thick grey fog - felt quite unique and added to the mystique. The sound of that bell is just incredible, and it's still ringing in my ears. There's a good progression of items and weapons over the course of the game, even if you have to work to find them, and I also found the level of enemy difficulty increased in proportion to the size of my arsenal - it never became too easy or too hard. I absolutely loved using the bow, and upgrading the weapons over time was very satisfying.On the more critical side, it is unfortunate that the shovel isn't available until later in the game, when one has already passed over many items that only it could dig up. Returning later with the shovel, I could hardly find any of those places without running aimlessly all over the maps again - though one is well rewarded for their diligence if they do so. When moving back and forth between areas, I frequently found myself facing the wrong direction and having to wait through two extra load screens. And the "listen" feature does get quite repetitive after a while, in time I ended up feeling like a supernatural courier with increasing lack of investment in the stories of the wraiths. I will say that I thought the story ended well, even if many questions are left unanswered and the overall ending was a bit bizarre. Room for a sequel? Unfortunately, a bug prevented me from finishing one of the final battles, so I had to watch the ending on YouTube as I really wanted to finish and wasn't willing to wait for a fix from the developers. It seems this game is still being developed and I came into it after many bugs had been fixed and improvements had been made, so I'm grateful for that at least, but I hope to see that last bug fixed soon so I can properly finish the game, and find the rest of the unique weapons and loot.I struggled a bit thinking of how to rate this game. Considering I found it uncommonly beautiful, clever, creepy and enjoyable to play, I want to give it a high score, and yet there are quite a few issues - including a bug that stopped me dead in my tracks at the very end of the game. I think a 7.5/10 is more than generous considering those issues, because despite them I still found myself quite obsessed with this game over the course of a few days. Happy to have snagged Betrayer during a Steam sale but I don't think full price is unreasonable for the roughly 11 hours of enjoyment I got out of it. I look forward to playing again down the road, perhaps with triple monitors finally set up. Recommended for all those who love mystery, horror, or just want to try something new. 7.5/10

Posted: November 2, 2014
												Best played in the dark, with the lights off, although you will still be startled by angry Spaniards and wraiths in the daylight.  Some adjustment is needed for your eyes to become accustomed to a monochrome world.  If you find the initial settings invite the onset of a migraine, you can fine tune, color, contrast, and brightness settings live in game to dial in a more pleasing palette.  Given that you are in a monochrome world, colors, when they appear can be startling and attention grabbing, so keeping the color settings close to original helps to deliver the atmosphere intended to work in concert with the directional sound, which really brings the game to life (even though you are surrounded by the dead).   Immersive sound is used for more than just surrounding you with various bird songs, insects, wind, stomping feet, and rustling foliage.  Directing you towards objects of interest, is an friendly shimmering sound while pressing X will fill your head with cacophony of echoing whispers that synchronize in stereo as you point your ears in the direction of the closest objective.  Sound used in this way, is far more satisfying and intuitive for locating objectives than simply being directed by a HUD and map.  Since the sound is directional, it alerts you to the presence of enemies around you and will make you jump out of your chair when they suddenly appear.  Conversely, you can startle your enemies, by sprinting towards them during a strong wind, thwacking them in surprise with your tomahawk, blasting them in the face with a cloud of black powder and shot, or haphazardly toss a black powder bomb their way.  Not burdened by a useless pile of trinkets to sift and sell,  what is found turns intal into coin to use for ammo, weapons, and charms, or is recorded as a clue in your journal.  Weapons and ammo can also be found and turned instantly into coin, if you find them lacking.  Just enough arrows and lead shot are held in your inventory to freely use the period weapons without fear of running out.  Conversely, you do not have an endless supply of ammo to freely send an endless volley of arrows like some games.  Arrows can be retrieved from corpses and the ground, so you can resupply at a fort less often.  Muskets and pistols take a few seconds to load, which adds an old world authenticity and charm that is strangely enjoyable and maddening as you scramble to reload, while a Spaniard does the same, trying to murder you from across a field.  A perfect game to play in the fall of the year on all hallow's eve surrounded by pumpkins, candles, and candy bars.

												If I had to describe this game in one word, I would say it was 'ambitious.' A black and white, open world, horror FPS set in the colonial era from a virgin studio? Most indies would rather churn out another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle/platformer. But does the execution live up to it's premise? Nope! Does it matter? Maybe.The stealth system is awful. Many of the later enemies have black and white color palettes, so you don't see them before they see you. Oh, and they can see you instantly from 50 yards away. There's a mechanic involving wind masking your sounds or something, but I never felt that it was worth the risk.And the game is plauged by a lack of variety. There are only five different weapon types, with varying qualities. There are only six or seven enemies. You can find equipment, but all it does is give you passive bonuses that are hardly even noticeable. Each zone in the game plays out the same way: find everything in the light world, find everything in the dark world, talk to ghosts and move on to the next zone. By the end of the game, you're sprinting from point A to point B just to finish the game. I haven't felt this kind of repetition since Assassin's Creed 1.Betrayer has a fairly solid engine. There's a myriad of graphics options and HUD options to choose from, which is always welcome from an indie dev. You can even skip the black and white aesthetic and play with color (recommended). That said, I did get stuck a couple times in the geometry, forcing me to kill my character and respawn.But if you can get past these shortcomings, the game is really interesting. The sound design is stellar. I can't think of any game that has such a robust audio department, much less one that is so integral to the mechanics of the game. When the story comes together it can be superb, but the story elements are all non-linear. Sometimes the story doesn't have the impact it should have because of this, even when dealing with incredibly grim topics like filicide.If you're a stickler for mechanics, I'd skip this title. 'Rough around the edges' doesn't even begin to describe my experience. However if you're more interested in atmosphere or story and you're not bothered by the broken stealth system, this game will entertain you for a few hours.

												Betrayer is a bit 50/50 in my opinion.My laptop isn't powerful enough to run it at full pelt graphically, so I can't speak for that, but visually, even on minimum, the game impresses. With the saturation maxed out, the forests and forts look beautifully lush and almost serene, whilst somehow still harbouring an air of creepiness in their design. Overall, I'd say it's impressive to look at.The story had me captivated too. It's pretty dark and fairly gritty in places, with the story slowly filling up with more gruesome deaths the further along you go. The storytelling is nice too, and the language conveys the events during and previous in a good way. There were times where I felt my emotions highten in a way that made me crave answers and more knowledge about a particular person or family. The game delivers well with it's background and lore.The ending was truly unexpected too. Like, seriously, what? But it was well done and quite sudden, in a way that took me completely by surprise.However, amongst the game's good points, I did find errors. I found that even on the lowest difficulty, the enemies could be outrageously hard when given a moment's chance to gang up on you, which became even more frustrating when the character started to walk backwards and to the side by itself. This made aiming at things and not dying almost impossible during certain sections of the game, especially toward the end. I don't know how many have suffered this issue, but beware of it before buying in case it happens to you too. Lots of rage was had.I also found parts of the game to be really boring. There's tons of running back and forth, and even when there isn't, there's tons of fast-travelling back and forth instead. I love it when video games feature fast travel, because it allows me to explore more, make sure I've found collectibles etc, but when the story heavily rests on using the feature, it becomes boring and stale, especially between environments that, as pretty as they are, look immensely similar.All in all I enjoyed the game. A lot of it looked rather appealing, the controls are easy to get to grips with, the controller support is generally good and the story was genuinely rivetting from time to time. A bit glitchy here and there and a tad frustrating too, but I recommend playing this anyway. Probably for fans of FPS games in general. 6/10.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												Best played in the dark, with the lights off, although you will still be startled by angry Spaniards and wraiths in the daylight.  Some adjustment is needed for your eyes to become accustomed to a monochrome world.  If you find the initial settings invite the onset of a migraine, you can fine tune, color, contrast, and brightness settings live in game to dial in a more pleasing palette.  Given that you are in a monochrome world, colors, when they appear can be startling and attention grabbing, so keeping the color settings close to original helps to deliver the atmosphere intended to work in concert with the directional sound, which really brings the game to life (even though you are surrounded by the dead).   Immersive sound is used for more than just surrounding you with various bird songs, insects, wind, stomping feet, and rustling foliage.  Directing you towards objects of interest, is an friendly shimmering sound while pressing X will fill your head with cacophony of echoing whispers that synchronize in stereo as you point your ears in the direction of the closest objective.  Sound used in this way, is far more satisfying and intuitive for locating objectives than simply being directed by a HUD and map.  Since the sound is directional, it alerts you to the presence of enemies around you and will make you jump out of your chair when they suddenly appear.  Conversely, you can startle your enemies, by sprinting towards them during a strong wind, thwacking them in surprise with your tomahawk, blasting them in the face with a cloud of black powder and shot, or haphazardly toss a black powder bomb their way.  Not burdened by a useless pile of trinkets to sift and sell,  what is found turns intal into coin to use for ammo, weapons, and charms, or is recorded as a clue in your journal.  Weapons and ammo can also be found and turned instantly into coin, if you find them lacking.  Just enough arrows and lead shot are held in your inventory to freely use the period weapons without fear of running out.  Conversely, you do not have an endless supply of ammo to freely send an endless volley of arrows like some games.  Arrows can be retrieved from corpses and the ground, so you can resupply at a fort less often.  Muskets and pistols take a few seconds to load, which adds an old world authenticity and charm that is strangely enjoyable and maddening as you scramble to reload, while a Spaniard does the same, trying to murder you from across a field.  A perfect game to play in the fall of the year on all hallow's eve surrounded by pumpkins, candles, and candy bars.

Betrayer

... Well what is it? What will I get from it? and possibly the most important question of them all how much will it cost me, and is it worth my hard earned money? (for me yes)What is it... A PC game that will delight, astound and more than a few times have you jumping out of your knickers. .It's neither a FPS nor a RPG although there is plenty of your friendly Skeletons (blow them apart), Spaniard/Spanish soldiers with demonic eyes, spiders and weird floating beast's to kill. How about a FPEGA (first person exploration ghostly adventure game). Blackpowder regard it as a first person action adventure game (Indie). What-ever call this Indie Game it's well thought out and extremely pleasing to play.Once you clear the first map you're on your way to a rather pleasant and rather unique game (my opinion).Your playing field is forest, forts, Indian villages, settler cabins and more forest. You should not expect any-thing else, after all, the game is set around 1604 colonial America, and this is were settlers set up homes in them days (forest and farming land), and tried to live in peace with the local Indians.The expanse of forests is (what can I say) massive and very much like reality. The attention paid to the greenery. grass, trees, plants, worn pathways all tremendous detail... superb. Buildings, boulders, flags flying, forts very much what you would expect to see, if it was possible to time travel back to that era.The only gripes I have is the use of the sound director. When trying to find all the chests, which I did near the end of the game, could for me have had a greater range. It was like looking for a needle in a haystack at times, and voice over. These guys have still come up with the goods on limited funds. Me... I am a dedicated RPG fan known to sometimes play First Person Shooters, Action Adventures, MMO's and Multi-Player games. I found this game to be a refreshing change and will put these guys at the top of my list and keep my eyes open for their next release... May the force be with you

PREMISE:Betrayer could best be described; and as others have already listed, a stealth based mystery game that relies on exploration as a means of driving the story forward. It takes place during the colinzation of the new world in 1604 by charters set out by both the Engilsh and Spanish Empires. You begin the game shipwrecked on the beach, further inland you run into the only "living" human you will to talk to the entire game; a Maiden in Red, she has no memeory of what happend to cause the various settlements you find throughout the game to be full of the Pompeii esque remains of the Colinists and why no one living seems to remain. Unraveling the secret past of the Maiden in Red and of the former Colonies as well as its inhabitants is up to you. MECHANICS / GAMEPLAY:The game does have combat; and while nothing too eather shattering, is more than adaquate for what the game sets out to do. The game gives you variuos choices weapons that all play distinctly different from eachother and have their own pros and cons. For instance the bows (silent, faster to fire) and black powder weapons (stronger, but load and long reload). The differences in the weapons do warrant some thought before rushing into fights when wandering the map, however during other times the games brings the enemies to you making it more a questions of what is able to ill the fastest.  You also get charms that buff your chracter as well as throwables in the form explosives and tomahawks. I really didn't use the latter much. The story is progressed forward by the players ability to ring a bell and transfer from the normal white washed world to a extremely dark "spirit world". Within the spirit world you will meet key wraiths, as well as secondary shadows of the former colonits whose spirits that are still bound to the world for one reason or another. It is here that you will you will unravel most of the mysteries of the New World Colonies.  From the first wraiths you encounter in any given area you will usually be given a short incomplete narrative. It is then up to you to  fill in the gaps using clues you find in the living world in order to refresh the wraiths memories and finish their stories. This is where I major give major cudos to who ever wrote the various stories of the wraiths you enounter in game. What might at beginning the  sound like a story of somone consoling  a perons who just lost their father slowly begins to warp with each new clue you uncover and present to the wraiths.This continues until  the story evolves into someone being murdered and another executed. By the conlcusion of each investigation the original phrase thrown out by the wraith will have usually taken on a whole new context and meaning. Writing of this nature is not always an easy feat, and is something I'd like to see more of in the video game realm. BREIF CONCLUSION:Would I recommend this game? Not necessarily to everyone, if you enjoy mystery, interesting writing, and something different, then yes this game is probably for you and you would like it. I bought the game on sale for 2.49, I really would have been content with what I got for 10 dollars.  As some of the negative reveiws can attest it won't appeal to everyone. My major gripe is that the game does get slightly repetative, new enemies are thrown in at later areas. These enemies are fairly interesting and have interesting mechanics, but their newsheen does fade rather quickly. There were about 6 or 7 different areas, and the game started to turn more into work by then end, but the story kept me going to see it through to the end. If I were to apply a number rating for those who care, I would give this game a very solid 7 maybe a shaky 8.MY TIPS TO ANYONE WHO BUYS:*You do get the shovel eventually. Yes you will have to backtack to dig up some of the things you find earlier in the game.*Stealth is slightly less useful in the spirit world, but still applicable. *Pick up everything you can in the map before entering the spirit world in any area, in my opinion this is the best way to get everything done in the quickest way possible.

Posted: March 1, 2016
												I was going to write a list of "Pros and Cons," but then I realized that although the pros were things done well, the cons were things the game didn't even try to do, because it wasn't about those things.  So, I re-wrote the list as "Things This Game Is and Is Not About."  "Bottom Line" at the top, for TL;DR purposes.Bottom Line:This is not a triple-A title, and it isn't trying to be.  It's trying to go in a different direction and do things that triple-A titles *don't* do, and specifically avoid doing the things they already do better.  If you like the "Things This Game Is About," and are not bothered by a total lack of "Things This Game Is Not About," then you will like this game, because it is VERY good at what it *is* about.  However, if you find the game "too slow," "boring," "lacking weapon diversity," or "not challenging enough," then this game is a poor match for you, because it is not about scratching those types of itches.Things This Game Is About:~ Spooky atmosphere.  Not frightening, shocking, or horrifying - just slightly spooky.  Something is... *off*.~ Exploration.  There are numerous ways to pick your way through the game, but turning on all the map markers and following the optimal path will be tremendously boring.  Instead, exercise a bit of self-control and wait to turn on those markers until you've found most of the stuff but aren't sure where those last two or three things are.~ Isolation.  This is a doomed colony, and you're there to sort out the wreckage, not interact with a cast of dozens of vibrant and interesting NPCs.~ Paying attention to what you hear (and how audible you are) more than what you see.  The devs wanted to create a game where aural cues are more important than visual ones, and while there are still visual cues for the hearing-impaired, the aural cues are far more important and reliable.~ Helping ghosts make peace with their deaths, which they can't remember, by figuring it out for them.  You may well piece together a story before the ghost does, but they might need some object or other trigger to be able to move on.  Just accept that this is how ghosts work - it's about their peace, not your understanding.~ Patiently planning your attacks.  More like Tenchu (the first one), where you can get in over your head if you fail to spot something, than like Shadow of Mordor, where you're *supposed* to overcome superior odds and adapt your plans on the fly.  Actually, it's even farther in the Tenchu direction than Tenchu is.Things This Game Is Not About:~ Broad weapon choices (would be period-inappropriate).~ Slaughtering your enemies in droves (would detract from the atmosphere).~ Fast-paced gameplay (would detract from the atmosphere).~ Being super-exciting, epic, or over-the-top in any way (would detract from... look, this is a very understated game).~ Magic spells, talent trees, mega bosses, epic weapons, phat lewtz, or pretty much anything that most triple-A titles go over-the-top on to try to stand out from their competitors.~ Puzzles.  The "investigations" you undertake, such as they are, are not intellectually demanding.  There are no puzzles in this game, no intuitive leaps to make; if you can just find the MacGuffins the ghosts are looking for, they'll fill in part of the colony's story for you and be able to move on themselves.  This is not a framework for a puzzle, it's a justification of the fetch-quest mechanic (the ghosts are stuck, therefore they can't go on their own errands).

Could I have finished it faster? Probobly. Should I have? No, since I enjoyed exploring, trying new tactics, and just generally goofing around while playing it. Looking at the reviews of Betrayer on the popular gaming news sites would give someone the impression that Betrayer is an okay game at best, filled with repetative, boring moments at the end. Dew and Doritos at every chance they can, so they can go ♥♥♥♥ off. +Secondly, there was not a single moment in the game that I didn't enjoy. I died a few times, sure, but I never got upset at it.+I've never felt my heart race while playing a video game before, but Betrayer did that for me. Crouching in the shadows, hearing the Loon calls of the savage Burned Men getting louder as they got closer and searched for me, I couldn't help but grow anxious, and when their calls turned to War-Whoops (well, louder, more agressive Bird Calls...) I felt a shivver run down my spine.+I've never felt such satisfaction with completing Side-Quests and hunting for Treasure, in any video game, but Betrayer made me feel very, very satisfied. 												If I had to sum this game up, it would be that the devs tried making a game that people would want to play, rather then making a game people would want to keep playing.This game has a unique look with a monochrome art style that uses red to show points of interest, and if that's not your thing you can switch to full colour or anything inbetween. The game also does very little hand holding as it gives you a few tips of how the game works at the beggining but after that the game expects you to explore and work out everything else by yourself which isnt exactly a bad thing as I enjoyed the game more for it simply letting me work out things on my own.The combat however is just awful, I liked the idea of using a bow to silently take out enemies and how you can use the wind to mask the noise you make but I found this was just a waste of time as enemies can spot you quite easily if your not crouching and the render distance for the red colouring that makes the enemies stand out is rather low. Enemies can only be silently killed so long as you hit them in the head with a bow or melee them, but if the arrow doesnt kill them every enemy for a few hundred miles round will know exacly where you are.The gameplay itself isnt all that bad as you explore the area looking for clues and chests but after the first hour or so you will quickly grow bored of it as you will find that you've experienced everything this game has to offer after about 20 minutes. Run to the marker on your map, collect treasue, kill enemies nearby rinse and repeat. The story is also lackluster with an ending that just left me wondering why the devs even bothered adding it in.Even after all these faults though I found myself enjoying the experience the whole way through even when I knew I was just repeating the same mundane steps the whole way through. If you give the game a chance I'm sure you will enjoy it even though it has many glaring issues.

Posted: April 24, 2016
												3 hours of trying to figure out if I'm the titular BetrayerThe Basics: 16th century First person mystery/explorationPrevious Time Spent: noneExpectation of learning Curve: low Why I bought this: I've read a decent number of reviews, and been told specifically to get into it by a close friend. Additionally, this seemed inspired by the lost Roanoke Colony, which seemed novelFirst Impressions: Betrayer has a striking look achieved by the use of monochrome and red. It also is a great game to play with the headphones on, and just get blown away by the sensory experience. You definitely feel transported to a different place. Wind blows around, moving the trees, and terrifying apparitions attack. There's a sense of danger and a great mystery hook.  My 3 Hours with the Game:You begin shipwrecked on the shores of the new world, wandering to a colony that has clearly failed. As mentioned previously, the use of color is great, and there's a very real sense of being in another time and place. There's great use of sound, such as rushing wind, and the combat is tense, frightening, and novel. Betrayer didn't need to be a first person shooter in order to accomplish the atmospheric storytelling,  but the combat wasn't unwelcome either. I hit some initial technical frustrations with the game, involving odd controls, but after a bit of internet digging, I was able to solve this. I appreciated the fact that in spite of being a game that leads you from waypoint to waypoint, I was able to actually get stuck in the plot early on, requiring some more sleuthing, and use of the listening power (which I had previously ignored). I spent most of my time seeking out clues, following them, talking to ghosts and uncovering tantalizing clues to the doom that fell over this colony, which seemed to have multiple factors, from the geopolitical to the fantastical.  My highlight:The first time I rang the bell in the first fort, and found myself in the night world, able to speak to ghosts and presented with more fantastical enemies. The sounds were effective and quite frightening, and the realization that I could go through and deal with the corruption that had begun blighting the land was heartening. (Plus, who doesn't want to fight skeletons under black skies with a slowly reloading musket?)My verdict: I'd strongly recommend giving this a shot(but maybe on a steam sale). The atmosphere is great, and the sense of danger inherent in fighting well armed monsters with a bow, musket or other 17th century weapon feels very real. There's a great frantic sense to reloading a musket while being charged by a squad of Spanish Soldiers (who seem like revenants or ghouls). Additionally, the story is fairly interesting, however I did get a bit of a sense of repetition after hitting hour 3, as much of the gameplay involves searching for waypoints on the map, clearing them, learning clues and talking to ghosts before preceding. -Jon

												Story: 9/10      The story is fantastic. Sometimes a little hard to follow and it seems to repeat itself a little at times, but I still found the story so gripping that I didn't want to stop playing until I finished the first area. **EDIT: 3.2 hours was the time it took to clear the first and second area, I was going a little quick though.**Graphics: 8.5/10      The graphics are very good for such a low price game, but still have occasional issues. Certain things encountered appear blocky and rectangular, when they in fact should flow smoothly. I'm running on the highest graphic setting with a Radeon R9 290 GPU.Physics/Mechanics/Engine: 8/10... Actually, 9/10      The combat is my only complaint. One could be aimed right at the head of an enemy at relatively close range, and the projectile will act like you're aiming well above your target, or to the right/left. A point-blank headshot turns into a projectile sailing 3 feet above their head. Another downside, if one of your projectiles gets stuck higher up in a tree; don't bother jumping to try and grab it. You just end up looking like a cat chasing a laser pointer. That said, a cool feature is certain projectiles can ricochet off armor, and still be retrievable (if one can find them.) My favorite feature though, is the use of directional sounds/hearing. Very well implemented, instills a good sense of distance/direction unlike some other games.Pricing: 11/10      I bought the game on sale, curious at it's low price tag lowered even further by the sale. Looking deeper and reading other reviews, I decided to give the game a try. I'm glad I did, I feel as though by getting this on sale I practically stole it at $1.50 (or what ever the price of the sale was). I'd definitely have been happy if I still paid full price.Atmosphere: 10/10      Many "horror" games claim they're soooo scary. All those games have is jumpscares with no build up. This game is different! It holds a very creepy atmosphere, and nowhere feels safe. When I play, I'm constantly looking behind and listening to the various noises hostiles will make. To me, this is a true horror game, not just another jump-scare fest. Eyes also hold a strong sense of fear for me, so when one of the types of hostiles got so close to me I could see them, I got goosebumps. A game hasn't given me goosebumps like that in a long long time.TL/DR: Buy the game. If you like a horror game that can hold it's atmosphere and has a good story, you will be pleased.

												[Update]Nomination for "I thought this was cool before it won an award."-------Betrayer is a fantastic game. It combines elements of horror, mystery, playing detective, and discovery in a 1604 colony establishing itself in Virginia, tied together with a strong narrative. While investigating disappearences and unearthing the fate of the colonists, the player travels across a gorgeously designed world. Think Miasmata style exploration, with the stealth of archery, or the braziness of muskets and pistol combat should the player choose.The engine runs very well, and looks stunning. The game features a black and white filter, the strength determined by the player, who can choose true greyscale or saturate the colours as vivid or dull as they choose. Certain elements of the world remain red regardless.The combat is very well done, the weapons are very responsive, and the archery behaves exceptionally well.Even just exploring the world makes this game the comfy simulator so many people desire.To top it all off, the writing builds a world of characters so vivid and varied that you'd be hard pressed to stop playing, lest you not know what happens/happened next.Absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking for a comfy experience, or a middle ages, colonial setting horror or mystery.

												Too bad there is no neutral option, so I had to choose to recommend it.This is a weird one. The game definitely got flaws, a lot of them. It's not very well fleshed out in general, to be honest. But it is very, very compelling where it's at its strongest.Betrayer is noticeably repetitive and doesn't have many engaging mechanics, and the ending is considered puzzling, cliffhanger or even lackluster by many. But its creepy, atmospheric setting, striking presentation(which you can fine-tune to your liking!) and brilliant sound design more than make up for its flaws. All exposition is provided via text, however, and there is little environmental storytelling. It tries to be an semi-open-world RPG, but to be honest it's much closer to a fetch-quest driven FPS with RPG elements.It's an atmosperic, immersive story of how flawed humans are. Overall, this game is kinda closer to its artsy-fartsy kin, rather than to mechanichally competent products. Posted: February 17, 2015
												Disturbing story, leaves you thinking... Violent stuff has happened and you must find out who did it (find artefacts and present them to related 'persons', no puzzle other than finding the stuff in the first place), and ultimately you must judge whether or not those people should be set free or left to torment on their deeds. Boils down to a binary choice, yes, but it made me think about stuff I probably wouldn't otherwise.Game-play is quite fun, actually, with you exploring several right sized locations for items and 'people' to talk about those items. The maps are populated with some enemies, that re spawn when die, and a nice mechanic is implemented to let you approach those enemies with some stealth. You also have perfect indication if you have been spotted or not, as well as noises that you learn to recognize that point to nearby enemies - which can be pretty hard to spot when not enraged and charging you. New enemies (with accompanying attack mechanics, mostly hit and run but with different flavours) are introduced at a right pace. At least one of them made me jump when they first showed up, which for me is quite hard to achieve in games where the character has some means to defend itself... You must also use a nice mechanic to switch to 'dark mode', which changes the enemies, the colour scheme turns dark, and severely limits your view range. The idea is to explore in light mode, mark up the spots (by hand or by cellphone photos, as the map has no marker functions) and then revisit some places when you have the equipment or on the right mode to progress in story. You also can ask for audio and visual cues to where you should go next, which will help you find the elements relevant to the story.Overall the game was a dark and tense experience but also a quite enjoyable exploration. You are not powerless or forced to do stealth, and although you are encouraged and should use it to at least dispatch the stronger enemies first in a surprise attack, charging up in the right zig-zag pattern might left you alive at the end. Still I recommend do not panic and remember an axe to the face is quite effective in discouraging those pesky charging foes.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												A compelling tale of discovery, ghosts, regret and, naturally, betrayal.You travel around a section of woodland near the coast of the New World with no real understanding of who you are or what you must do, meeting variuos trapped spirits along the way. Each wraith you encounter has its own unique baskstory, which normally ties into the stories of the other wraiths in the area. There is areally chilling overarching plotline which retains a couple of eerily ambiguous elements and it only picks up speed as you go through the game.This is a superb short game (you could grind it out in a week easily, and I fully suggest you do so) but not without content. True, there could be a bit more variation in the maps/objectives, but that's really not what this game is about; rather it is something to play slowly and contemplatively, exploring every tree stump and rock face and traversing every inch of the woodland on the hunt for clues. It somehow avoids being boring despite being really much of the same for the duration.The graphics are great and run wonderfully, the sound design is EXCELLENT and is one of the few games I can think of where sound was actually an aspect which jumped out at me, and the gameplay is simplistic and smooth. Loot and weapons are fairly standard, but you do find some interesting variations on the same weapons as you get later in the game. There are multiple incarnations of each weapon type, getting progressively stronger as the game progresses.At the start of the game you feel so weak, only being able to take on a couple of enemies at once at a push, stealth really is the preference for early game. Towards the end, however, it is possible to find weapons capable of taking down a skeleton in one hit, even the floating skulls are no match for you near the end, but combat is not the focus of the game and you never feel overpowered.My favourite aspect of Betrayer is the level of customisation the game gives you. you can choose to play the game in black and white or colour, with variable saturation, as well as having control over the enemy difficulty at any point in the game. The best part of customisation, however, is the map, which you can set to display the locations of various goals, or, as I prefer, not. It is useful to be able to turn these settings on after the plot draws to a close for completionists out there, just so you can polish off the few chests you might have missed.One downside is that it also seems to highlight chests/objectives you have previously attained in the map, although this only happens once you return to an area you have previously visited. I also noticed that, at one point in the game, it decided to invert the stereo; so what should have been in my right ear was suddenly in my left visa vera, which was incredibly disorientating in game which utilises sound to direct you to the wraiths. However the fix was easy, as I just swapped my headphones round.Apart from these two very minor greivances, Betrayer is a great game from such a small developer and at a great price. I fully recommend it to anyone looking for an atmospheric daytime-horror game. Theres something in this game which is certainly creepier and more harrowing than any xenomorph jumping through the air vents. Its more subtle than that. Buy this game.

Posted: April 24, 2016
												3 hours of trying to figure out if I'm the titular BetrayerThe Basics: 16th century First person mystery/explorationPrevious Time Spent: noneExpectation of learning Curve: low Why I bought this: I've read a decent number of reviews, and been told specifically to get into it by a close friend. Additionally, this seemed inspired by the lost Roanoke Colony, which seemed novelFirst Impressions: Betrayer has a striking look achieved by the use of monochrome and red. It also is a great game to play with the headphones on, and just get blown away by the sensory experience. You definitely feel transported to a different place. Wind blows around, moving the trees, and terrifying apparitions attack. There's a sense of danger and a great mystery hook.  My 3 Hours with the Game:You begin shipwrecked on the shores of the new world, wandering to a colony that has clearly failed. As mentioned previously, the use of color is great, and there's a very real sense of being in another time and place. There's great use of sound, such as rushing wind, and the combat is tense, frightening, and novel. Betrayer didn't need to be a first person shooter in order to accomplish the atmospheric storytelling,  but the combat wasn't unwelcome either. I hit some initial technical frustrations with the game, involving odd controls, but after a bit of internet digging, I was able to solve this. I appreciated the fact that in spite of being a game that leads you from waypoint to waypoint, I was able to actually get stuck in the plot early on, requiring some more sleuthing, and use of the listening power (which I had previously ignored). I spent most of my time seeking out clues, following them, talking to ghosts and uncovering tantalizing clues to the doom that fell over this colony, which seemed to have multiple factors, from the geopolitical to the fantastical.  My highlight:The first time I rang the bell in the first fort, and found myself in the night world, able to speak to ghosts and presented with more fantastical enemies. The sounds were effective and quite frightening, and the realization that I could go through and deal with the corruption that had begun blighting the land was heartening. (Plus, who doesn't want to fight skeletons under black skies with a slowly reloading musket?)My verdict: I'd strongly recommend giving this a shot(but maybe on a steam sale). The atmosphere is great, and the sense of danger inherent in fighting well armed monsters with a bow, musket or other 17th century weapon feels very real. There's a great frantic sense to reloading a musket while being charged by a squad of Spanish Soldiers (who seem like revenants or ghouls). Additionally, the story is fairly interesting, however I did get a bit of a sense of repetition after hitting hour 3, as much of the gameplay involves searching for waypoints on the map, clearing them, learning clues and talking to ghosts before preceding. -Jon

												If I had to sum this game up, it would be that the devs tried making a game that people would want to play, rather then making a game people would want to keep playing.This game has a unique look with a monochrome art style that uses red to show points of interest, and if that's not your thing you can switch to full colour or anything inbetween. The game also does very little hand holding as it gives you a few tips of how the game works at the beggining but after that the game expects you to explore and work out everything else by yourself which isnt exactly a bad thing as I enjoyed the game more for it simply letting me work out things on my own.The combat however is just awful, I liked the idea of using a bow to silently take out enemies and how you can use the wind to mask the noise you make but I found this was just a waste of time as enemies can spot you quite easily if your not crouching and the render distance for the red colouring that makes the enemies stand out is rather low. Enemies can only be silently killed so long as you hit them in the head with a bow or melee them, but if the arrow doesnt kill them every enemy for a few hundred miles round will know exacly where you are.The gameplay itself isnt all that bad as you explore the area looking for clues and chests but after the first hour or so you will quickly grow bored of it as you will find that you've experienced everything this game has to offer after about 20 minutes. Run to the marker on your map, collect treasue, kill enemies nearby rinse and repeat. The story is also lackluster with an ending that just left me wondering why the devs even bothered adding it in.Even after all these faults though I found myself enjoying the experience the whole way through even when I knew I was just repeating the same mundane steps the whole way through. If you give the game a chance I'm sure you will enjoy it even though it has many glaring issues.

Posted: May 2, 2016
												TL:DR Gameplay: simple, Graphics: quirky Story: It's goooood. Buy the gameIt comes across as a standard First person shooter in a lot of respects, namely melee feels weak sauce and you're only real weapons are ranged. At time of writing I haven't actually finished the game but I still recommend it but that's more for the story and the different take on things.The game is initially set in black and white (and red) but you can put colour in the game if you want. Personally I'm playing in the black and white (And red) because the effect is just so damned cool. I say black and white (and red) for the simple fact of thats what it is. Everything apart from items of interest, namely enemies, are in black and white. The enemies have a flash of red on them which helps them stick out. So far I've been in three seperate large areas which require exploring in two different states fighting spirits, skeletons and conquistadors. Each area has a story to unfold and various items to find to solve them with. The stories themselves unfold nicely and in the first at least sent a little shiver up my spine.The combat is stealth based if you can but you can hold your own in, for lack of a better word, firefight. The searching for goodies is a nice take on a compass where you use your "ears" and triangulate yourself towards the place/item/individual.Not wishing to give too much away despite this game being a few months old now I'll leave you to discover that one.All in all I'd recommend this game on the basis of that the company is trying something new and what they've created is both beautiful in design and implementation.

Posted: March 30, 2016
												Not gonna lie, not recommending this game proved to be a hard decision.  I really wanted to like it, and even fooled myself to for a time, a somewhat refreshing look at a stealth-horror-investigation-shooter?  Here are the reasons that made this game was hard to downvote.-Amazing environment-Unique Story-Solid Gameplay-Very Fair PriceNow with a list like that, how could I damn such a game?  Well the combat did prove enjoyable though the enemy variety proved to be fairly bland, not the types or number, just how they had the same behavior and mode of attack.  That along with the give and take story that really demanded finishing.  Once you spend an hour or two in the game, you realize it is rather shallow and becomes a grinding Easter egg hunt, wrought with cheap scares to keep you on your toes until you are upgraded enough that you no longer care to be tactical or stealthy.  Then it’s fast traveling back and forth, as well as revisiting areas you’ve scoured already.  The dialogue proved dreadful as well as many systems that appear mostly hollow, like gifting your red friend things you’ve dug up like an obedient puppy and not much to show for regardless of if she accepts it or not.  The game isn’t spotless either as I have also found myself on more than one occasion being lodged into rocks and walls maneuvering with a borderline useless jump key.  Speaking of environments, I hope you like forests, because that is all you are going to get in this game.  So if you are into a cheap romp through the woods with a passible story where you collect junk kill skeletons and talk to ghosts for 5 hours, feel free go on ahead.  I just can’t, although I can safely say I gave the game the benefit of finishing it at least.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												This is a bit of a tough one seeing as I know some won't enjoy this style of game. Betrayer is a mystery solving, partially open world adventure game with FPS and horror elements. It takes place in the early 1600's right after the North American New World begins to be settled by European Powers.To start off, those looking for an all action FPS single-player game may be disappointed to find the action here is a lot slower then you may like because of authenticity to the era. Combat makes up roughly ~40% of the game, solving mysteries and the main story makes up another ~40% and the final ~20% goes to free-roaming adventure, finding chests, places to dig, etc...The games high points are the environment and atmosphere are which both unique in usage and awesome for keeping true to the time period. The story progression is smooth and interesting (provided you read the text) and the difficulty in combat ramps up fairly as new enemies and weapons are introduced. Though some find the game to be repetitive, each area had enough to explore and complete to keep me occupied and remain interested throughout. Overall, I recommend this game for those seeking a unique experience filled with murder and mystery.Optional: If you are an achievement hunter most of the achievements are easy enough to be done without the use of guides (as long as you pick up everything and complete the whole story) although you will certainly need a 2nd play-through to grind enough enemies for the killing achievements (I farmed the Fort Hope conquistador part for kills but there are other spots too).

Posted: November 23, 2016
												StoryYou strand with a ship on some Island during the times of colonisation, but something is wrong with the Spanish soldiers stationed there and all the inhabitants are dead. The only friendly person is the maid in red, who cannot remember her past and in some mysterious dark side of the world, skeletons and ghosts are haunting the Island. Can you escape the Island? The story is mostly told by Ghosts and Notes, though nobody in the game is voiced, meaning that you will have to read a lot. Though the story seems very deep and is, I did not really follow it, because of the reading close until the end and do not feel like I missed anything between start to finish. GameplayIn first person you run around and try to progress while fighting the mysterious creatures. You have a weapon arsenal of bows, crossbows, pistols, rifles and Tomahawks, which all have their advantages and disadvantages; though the tomahawk is in my opinion not balanced and the best (one shots nearly everything). Whenever you find a bell in the area you can use it to enter the dark world where there are different enemies, but also ghosts of the dead that might be able to give you important information. Sadly, you can simply use your listening ability to hear where the next objective is. This makes thinking unnecessary and you might just run from a to b like a dummy just to do the same thing in the next stage of the game again.GraphicsThe graphics make this game so unique. The world around you is only black, white, black and red which give the game such a sad or depressed filter. At first I thought it was great, but after several hours you do not want to be in that world doing the same stuff over and over.It really is a good game and I sometimes did enjoy playing it, but the repetitive gameplay and the sad world can bring you down. I personally did not enjoy it most of the time, but I can understand the people that do. At some point I only continued so that the game would be over sooner, so If someone says he wants the game and thinks it is cool, buy it, 5€ is no big deal, especially during sales, but I thought so as well at first, so do not have to high expectations, because I at the end cannot recommend it for the fun I had playing it.

												I would really like to like this game, however, i can't.Let me pick apart the gameplay featured and the problems associated with it.Stealth is atrocious and flat and more or less always ends in you pulling all surrounding enemys and then having top perform a action shooter like dance with weapons that arent meant for this at all. It doesn't help that apparently the worse bows have to seem a spread (?, that is not how bows work) that make hitting enemys stealthily in the head a russian roulette.Shootinghas no impact, although it should be different with the weapons choosen by the designers. But together with the laserfocused and telepathic AI, what is most likely suppossed to invoke combat like that from the movie The Patriot instead becomes a disgracefull jump and run.Exploration and Storyis empty. The world is empty and barren and you have to explore everything twice because you also need to do it in the shadow- or otherworld. The Story is rather intriguing, however since you have to scour the world twice with the above mentioned problems come to bare and make trying to unravel the story a chore.Would i recommend it.Not really, especially if you can grab Skyrim wich makes all these things above far better. Yeees, i know, it is an indiegame thing however at the end of the day you have to compare and especialy Skyrim and to the current prize you can get it, especially during sales, offers far more and in better quality.And that is before modding.However, i would argue if you are still interested youn wont really loose anything by that prize or even when it is at sale.

												Overall, Betrayer has a few issues, but it is well worth playing through even so, and certainly worth its low price point.+Great theme and tone, the environment is nicely eerie and the enemies are legitimately frightening.+The game world is unique and the locations are memorable; I found myself beginning to recognize different interesting parts of the forest.+Nice selection of weapons with distinct advantages and disadvantages.+Interesting, well-written dialogue and story.+Just right in terms of difficulty, not too easy or difficult.+Adjusting the color saturation after your first playthrough makes the game feel completely different on subsequent plays, which is fun.-The stealth is is very hit-and-miss, which is especially problematic at the beginning of the game when you need to use it the most (i.e., before you start finding the more powerful weapons).-Using a gamepad makes some of the menus and map screen really difficult and unintuitive to use.  If, like me, you're a weirdo who likes using a controller for these kind of games, you'll quickly end up grabbing the mouse for using the maps at the very least. -There is at least one item that can be permanently missed out on if you don't choose the exact right dialogue options/use a walkthrough.  This probably isn't a huge issue for most people, but it irks me.-The "thief" enemies are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and catching them all is incredibly tedious.

Posted: January 12
												Good atmosphere, interesting use of colour and lack of colour.  There is a colour saturation slider, you can play in black and white with greys and red as your only "colour", or anything between that and full, bright and vibrant colours.Unique day/night cycle.  I can't say more, you just have to trust me on this one.Lots of stories unfold during the game.  Again, I can't say more without risk of ruining it.Fights are often challenging, even later in the game when gear has been improved.  Some surprises pop up now and again.  The game's set back when black powder weapons were getting a bit better, but armour was still in use as were bows and crossbows.  Your melee weapon never changes, but you can use several kinds of bows, firearms and crossbows.  Most use different ammo, so it's worth mixing and matching so you can maximize your ammunition.Stealth - it works.  Use it.  Or not, but be ready for a mob of enemies if you start a fight in the wrong place.  Woe to those who are unprepared.  The wind can mask your movement, and crouching keeps you low and quiet.The combat's not perfect, but it's fairly good.  Score a good long-range headshot with a bow on a nasty opponent and drop him without giving away your position, if the shot hits true and does enough damage.  It may not - there's a ricochet mechainc, as in certain weapons have a chance to bounce off anything that has armour.  Some weapons bounce a lot, some never.  You've got lots of options for weapons, and trinkets that boost your health, speed, reload speed, stealth, and a few other things but you're limited to 3 equipped so you have to tailor them to your play style.  No levels, or stats, but improved gear makes a big difference.Guns make noise.  Expect enemies to come running if they're fairly close when you fire.  Enemies can alert other enemies, too... so if you don't finish them off fast anyone in earshot might come running to their aid.Anyway, just for the atmosphere this one's worth it.  A pretty solid 8/10.  Get this one on sale, or not, and you might be glad you did.*** EDIT ***Just finished it, the sound is what sticks with me the most.  The sound is such a huge part of the game.  Turn it up and really listen.On a small down side - too much running around near the end.  Turns into a walking simulator with a few fights thrown in.  Okay, more than a few.  But they're mostly too easy at this stage.  If the game was much longer, I'd have likely lost interest due to all the walking and re-visiting locations.  I think they got the length of the game about right given the content and story.Weapon balance - maybe needs some tweaking as to when you find the unique weapons, and maybe there are a few too many of them.  It feels like you're using junk for about the first half, but once you start finding the good weapons the combat gets way, way easier.  I'd like to see the items rebalanced a bit, and doled out at a different pace - a bit slower and spread out a bit more.  I found a very powerful weapon way too early and it really made one-one-one fights a joke from that point on.  One shot every time execpt for the large Conquistadors and the toughest Skulls.It felt like your character gets just a bit too good near the end, even the bigger fights near the end feel like they aren't very tough - and I only threw explosives once but I didn't need to.  I guess it's because of the healing mechanic - you can drink all four shots quickly and they work instantly.  You still have to be somewhat careful, but the early to mid-game was more challenging.  I guess I'm saying it could use a bit of a re-balance, but only a little.  It's not bad enough that it *needs* to be changed, it simply could be and I think it would make the game even better.Worth every cent, though.  Thanks Steam Sales. :)
